text.p: The following are the main stories from Thursday's Albanian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The newspaper's editorial says Albanians' faith in pyramid schemes has placed President Sali Berisha in a dilemma and is causing social troubles.
- Thousands of protesters demanding their money back from the Sude pyramid scheme clashed with Albanian riot police and many were injured.
- Sude, a pyramid scheme manager, told the crowd she had gone bankrupt.
- Leaders of the opposition Socialist party and the Social Democrats met depositors with the failed pyramid scheme and expressed support for their protest.
- Vebi Alimucaj, president of Vefa Holding, one of Albania's biggest companies and of a pyramid scheme, told depositors banks were to blame for stopping payments to them.
- Gjallica, a pyramid scheme company which suspended payments to its depositors last December, said it had postponed the re-start for another two weeks.
- People's Democracy Xhaferri pyramid scheme continues to give returns to depositors.
- The moment to imitate the Belgrade protests has come, a newspaper commentary says.
- The prosecutor's office might investigate all pyramid scheme companies, an undisclosed source told the newspaper.
- The committee of the Interparlimentary Union will discuss the case of the Socialists' jailed leader Fatos Nano in Geneva.
- The state should not stand aside while Albanians suffer from the tragedy of the pyramid schemes, the newspaper editorial says.
- Albanian television reported on the events at the bankrupt pyramid scheme Sude after months of silence on the most debated theme in the country.
- Sude, manager of a bankrupt pyramid scheme company, was arrested at midnight after angry depositors left the area surrounding her flat.
- The ruling Democratic Party calls on Albanians to stay away from pyramid schemes and said the state will intervene to rectify the situation.
